narrative.title: NIH Data Management and Sharing Plan

question.text: Types and amount of scientific data expected to be generated in the project

json.answer: The study will generate a diverse range of scientific data, including demographic and clinical datasets, standardized anxiety and resilience scales, behavioral task data, physiological measures (e.g., heart rate variability), and derived summary variables. The estimated amount of scientific data is substantial due to the longitudinal design, with multiple modalities collected across several time points. Notably, physiological data and raw task files will constitute a significant portion of the storage requirements.

question.text: Scientific data that will be preserved and shared, and the rationale for doing so

json.answer: All generated scientific data will be preserved and shared, including demographic and clinical datasets, standardized scales, behavioral task data, physiological measures, and derived variables. The rationale for sharing these data is to facilitate transparency, reproducibility, and further research into adolescent mental health, anxiety, and resilience mechanisms. Sharing these comprehensive datasets will enable other researchers to explore new hypotheses, validate findings, and contribute meaningfully to the field.

question.text: Metadata, other relevant data, and associated documentation

json.answer: To facilitate interpretation of the scientific data, the following metadata, other relevant data, and associated documentation will be made accessible: study protocols, data collection instruments, data dictionaries, README files explaining the structure and content of the datasets, and detailed descriptions of the methods used for data collection and analysis. These resources will provide essential context for understanding the data and reproducing the findings.

section.title: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

question.text: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

json.answer: Specialized tools and software are needed to access or manipulate some of the shared scientific data. Specifically, statistical analysis software (e.g., R, Python libraries such as Pandas and NumPy) will be necessary for manipulating and analyzing the datasets. Additionally, specialized software for handling physiological data (e.g., EDFbrowser for EEG data, HRV analysis tools) may be required. These tools are widely available in the research community, and instructions on how to access or use them will be provided in the README files accompanying the shared datasets.

To enable interoperability of datasets and resources, common data standards will be applied to the scientific data and associated metadata. The study will adhere to standardized formats for demographic and clinical data (e.g., CSV for tabular data), behavioral task data (e.g., JSON for structured data), and physiological measures (e.g., EDF for EEG data). Metadata will follow established standards for description, such as the Data Documentation Initiative (DDI) for social science data. For datasets where no consensus standards exist, best practices in data organization and documentation will be followed to ensure clarity and usability.

section.title: Element 4: Data Preservation, Access, and Associated Timelines

question.text: Repository where scientific data and metadata will be archived

json.answer: The scientific data and metadata arising from the project will be archived in the National Institutes of Health (NIH) National Library of Medicine's (NLM) repository, specifically the [National Center for Biotechnology Information (NCBI)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/), which includes databases such as the Database of Genotypes and Phenotypes (dbGaP) for sensitive data. For less sensitive data, repositories like figshare or Zenodo will be considered to maximize accessibility.

question.text: How scientific data will be findable and identifiable

json.answer: The scientific data will be made findable and identifiable through the assignment of a persistent unique identifier (e.g., DOI) for each dataset. Data will also be indexed using standard keywords related to adolescent mental health, anxiety, and resilience, facilitating discovery through repository search functions.

question.text: When and how long the scientific data will be made available

json.answer: The scientific data will be made available no later than the time of publication of the main findings or at the end of the performance period, whichever comes first. The data are expected to remain available for a minimum of 10 years following the completion of the project to allow for extensive use by the research community.

section.title: Element 5: Access, Distribution, or Reuse Considerations

question.text: Factors affecting subsequent access, distribution, or reuse of scientific data

json.answer: While maximizing data sharing is a priority, factors such as informed consent, privacy, and confidentiality protections may limit the extent of data sharing. Specifically, because the study involves human subjects (adolescents) and sensitive information, access to identifiable data will be controlled, and de-identified datasets will be shared wherever possible.

question.text: Whether access to scientific data will be controlled

json.answer: Access to certain scientific data, particularly those that could potentially identify individual participants or contain sensitive personal information, will be controlled. These data will be stored in secured repositories requiring approval for access, such as dbGaP, to protect participant privacy and confidentiality.

question.text: Protections for privacy, rights, and confidentiality of human research participants

json.answer:
To protect the privacy, rights, and confidentiality of human research participants, several measures will be taken: 
1. De-identification: Datasets shared publicly will be de-identified to remove any direct identifiers.
2. Consent: Broad consent for data sharing has been obtained from parents/guardians and assent from adolescents, with an understanding that data will be de-identified.
3. Certificates of Confidentiality: The study will apply for Certificates of Confidentiality to further protect against compelled disclosure of identifying information.
4. Secure Data Storage: Sensitive data will be stored on secure servers with restricted access.

section.title: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

question.text: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

json.answer: Compliance with this Data Management and Sharing Plan will be monitored and managed by the study's Principal Investigator (PI), in collaboration with the institution's research administration office. The PI, along with a designated data manager, will oversee data collection, storage, sharing, and ensure that all shared data are properly de-identified and documented. Regular checks (every 6 months) will be conducted to verify adherence to the plan, address any issues promptly, and update the plan as necessary to reflect changes in data management best practices or regulatory requirements. The institution's Information Technology department will provide support for data security and storage solutions. Annual reports to the funding agency will include updates on data sharing activities, ensuring transparency and accountability in data management and sharing practices.
